channel.title: Thead stopping
channel.description: well i got this thread, and i need to terminate it. when i run thread.stop() the thread state changes to TERMINATED. after its terminated i need to re start it, every time i try thread.start() an exception is thrown "java.lang.IllegalThreadStateException", is there any way for me to change the thread state back to NEW without making a new instance? or maybe another way of forcing a thread to terminate which allows me to re start it?

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:14, topic:246059”]You need a semaphore.

In java, an easy way to implement one is with synchronized methods to access a boolean value.

boolean running = true;

public synchronized void stopRunning(){
running = false;
}

public synchronized void startRunning(){
running = true;
}

public synchronized boolean getRunning(){
return running;
}

public void run(){
//assuming you want it to loop?
while(true){
if(!getRunning()){
Thread.sleep(somenumberofmilliseconds);
continue;
}
doStuff();
}
}

Don’t use deprecated methods, they aren’t deprecated because they work. They are deprecated because they won’t work as expected, they are broken.[/quote]
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Semaphore.html

[quote=“io9, post:15, topic:246059”][quote author=Coder xynt link=topic=322539.msg2550104#msg2550104 date=1227468967]
Add a boolean flag to the thread. Start it upon initialization but don’t let any statement(s) execute until it meets specified conditions. Example:

public void run() { while(true) { while(run) { //etc } try { sleep(100); } catch(InterruptedException e){} //sleep thread for 100 ms each loop to reuse memory } }
[/quote]
WHAT IF HE’S NOT AN IDIOT AND DOESNT WANT IT TO SUCK 9999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999 CPU USAGE WHILE IT’S IDLING?

Oh right, you’re too retarded to notice that.

[hr]

Ontopic:
Straight from the JVM.

public synchronized void start() { /** * This method is not invoked for the main method thread or "system" * group threads created/set up by the VM. Any new functionality added * to this method in the future may have to also be added to the VM. * * A zero status value corresponds to state "NEW". */ if (threadStatus != 0) throw new IllegalThreadStateException(); group.add(this); start0(); if (stopBeforeStart) { stop0(throwableFromStop); } }

PROTIP: EXTEND THREAD AND OVERRIDE START TO REMOVE THE CHECK. WINK WINK.
(by that i mean also override the target)[/quote]
Java threads run on native threads.
not emulated threads etc. You can’t start twice because its a operating system constraint / design.

[quote=“BAsh, post:19, topic:246059”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=322539.msg2558744#msg2558744 date=1228037975]

unless im mistaking, start0 is protected. so it cant be accessed form outside of java.lang?

The protected modifier allows only subclasses to access the field/method.
[/quote]
reflection. there is no other method to (attempt) to start a thread twice.[/quote]
reflection is not useful in this case

Moparisthebest:

Don’t try to hack around the JVM’s protections and just do it the right way from the beginning.

The JVM just wraps the underlining operating system thread type. Hacking the Java clases will not do much.
